ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Its a required part of the history major you learn a bit about the history writing process but really this is just an execution-focused class, not skill-acquiring.
I learned to plan and write a senior essay in the History major.

I improved my primary source research skills, improved my writing to make it more concise and efficient, developed a compelling historical question, and I started thinking about how my research and thesis might offer a new perspective in a broader historical inquiry. I was challenged in a way that I had not been before in any history seminar.

I learned that in reading secondary literature it is helpful to also look at the notes. I had a difficult time figuring out what specific, perhaps under-researched issue I was going to explore in my senior essay, but by looking into the details that were noted, but not fully elaborated upon in the literature I was reading I was able to locate a more precise topic. I also learned to go beyond the literature, and seek out oral testimony, which has been especially relevant for my topic. With the help of my advisor and librarian, I was able to figure out how to properly stage this kind of interview, which questions to ask, and how to best document it.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Very little guidance from the history department it is what you make of it.
I would appreciate more department-level guidance and I would swap the ten-page draft requirement for an outline requirement.

I think the greatest strength of my experience this semester was the deadlines that my advisor set for me in between. I feel like that sort of engagement is a necessity for the History Senior Essay and that most of the time when people are left to their own devices they don't end up in as good of a spot at the end of their first semester.
Communication from History department for logistics and deadlines

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: You need to take it to get a history degree.
Yes, to graduate with a history degree.
Yes! I would recommend both my advisor and the 2 semester thesis.
Yes, you have to take it!
